Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is about to cross the street without looking for oncoming traffic.
Expectation2: Coordinate with other air traffic controllers to ensure smooth traffic flow
Situation2: One aircraft is about to cross into the neighboring sector on a normal route.
Story: I stood at the intersection, headset pressed to my ear, eyes flicking between the radar screen and the world outside. My stepbrother, always impatient, was already halfway to the curb, earbuds in, oblivious to the rush of cars. I was supposed to look out for him—Mom’s words echoed in my mind: “He’s your little brother now. Keep him safe.” At the same time, my screen blinked with a warning: Flight 237 was approaching the sector boundary, and I needed to coordinate with the next controller. My supervisor’s voice crackled in my ear, expecting a prompt handoff. My heart pounded. If I shouted to my brother, I might miss the handoff and disrupt the flow of air traffic. If I focused on the aircraft, I might not reach him in time. Both roles demanded my full attention, both lives depended on me. I felt split in two, paralyzed by the weight of responsibility, torn between the sky and the street.
